Eddie

Most Europeans are aware of the Irish economic wonder. No doubt, many americans have heard about it as well. 
 
 Ireland had long been the poorest country in western Europe. In fact, many still associate Ireland with poverty. Up until 1987, the Irish economy was under-performing, unemployment was around 15%, inflation was rampant and economic growth was stagnating. But something happened in 1987. Since then, the Irish economy has experienced a breathtaking economic growth, slashed unemployment figures in half, stabilised the inflationary pressure and paid off a significant portion of the governmental debt. 
 
 Many analysts have tried to explain this remarkable progress with different aspects of the Irish economic and political life. Perhaps the most important development has been that Ireland has been able to attract a large amount of FDI`s (Foreign Direct Investments). Many multinational companies have opted to base their operations or move production to Ireland. This has slashed the unemployment figures as well as dramaticly increased the economic growth. But this in turn needs to be explained. 
 
 The inflationary pressure has been pressed down and been kept low, even though the quick growth. This cannot be explained by the fact that Ireland has managed to attract foreign capital. In fact, these two developments are in stark contrast to one another.
 
 My idea for this thread is to discuss the reason for the Irish success and wether/how the rest of Europe could learn from the Irish experience.
 
 Here are a few arguments/explanations I`ve encountered so far (keep in mind that they are not exclusive to one another but are rather complementary):
 
 * Lower corporate and income tax than the rest of Europe has attracted alot of foreign companies that wants a piece of the EU market.
 
 This could also mean that much of Irelands economic growth has been at the expense of the rest of EU. Perhaps a good example of how EU could encourage a "race-to-the-bottom" if no attempts to harmonize certain crucial tax rates are being made. 
 
 * A well educated and english speaking workforce has attracted foreign companies (ecpessially those from english speaking countries).
 
 This factor is also very interesting as Ireland can expect even more well-educated people to enter the workforce in just a few years. In fact, the dependancy ratio is expected to drop in the future due to large cohorts in the universities at the moment.
 
 * Substantial EU subsidies for investments in infrastructure has made Ireland internationally competative at the expense of the rest of EU. 
 
 Critics have pointed out that it`s rather obscene that poorer EU members (like Germany and Sweden) should pay for further investments in rich Ireland.
 
 * Corporatism in the 21th century. By centrally negotiating wages between three parties; labour union, employers organisation and government the Irish wage increases have been kept low even during rapid economic growth. This can both explain the low inflationary pressure as well as Irelands attraction for foreign companies (lower labour costs). Instead of massive wage increases, the government has compensated the labour unions with lower income taxes for their members. 
 
 An interesting paralell (at least to me :) ) could be drawn to Sweden in the 50ies and 60ies when the labour market parties in Sweden worked in unison to dampen the negative effects of expetionally high demand for labour.
 
 * The "catching-up" effect. As Ireland was (one of?) the poorest countries in western Europe in the 1970:ies, the explosive economic growth was not as remarkable at first. A developing economy naturally grows faster than a more matured economy. A simmiliar development during the nineties (albeit not as succesful) is Greece. The momentum of this "catching-up" effect may also make the living standards outpace more matured economies (Ireland is currently one of the richest western european countries). 
 
 Recent slow-down of the Irish economy gives credit to this explenation, allthough I wouldn`t recomend dissmising the Irish wonder because of this.
 
 So what do you think? Are there cultural and political factors I`ve missed (admitedly I`ve mostly looked at economic factors). Which explanation do you think carry the most power? What will happen to Ireland in the future and could the rest of Europe (or perhaps even the US) learn something from all of this?
 
 - Eddie
wilted_laughter

That's a pretty thorough assessment of the "celtic tiger". 
 
 What I might point out is that Ireland is now one of the three most globalised economies in the world now; we are heavily dependent on FDI and a global economic downturn would hit us much harder than other states with more home grown industries. The challenge facing Ireland now is to decrease its dependence on foreign investment and develop more of its own domestic industries with its new wealth; especially in the context of new EU members with an eye to following the Irish example and in the process could well steal our thunder.
 
 I cannot stress enough that EU membership in terms of the structural funding Ireland received and market access is crucial to Ireland's success. And the time has come for us to become net contributors to the EU budget.
georged

Not much I can add to your very thorough assessments other than stressing the impact of quality of education available within the work force:
 
 ~The quality of Ireland's education is exceptionally high. The independent IMD World Competitiveness Report ranks Ireland as the best in Europe for the quality of education which everyone receives. Six out of every 10 of Ireland's third level students major in engineering, science or business studies subjects.~ 
 
 Combining that level of education with what's considered one of the highest quality of life countries in Europe makes for a very formidable combination.

A question for the OP or those knowledgable on the topic:
 
 I travelled to Dublin a few years ago (beautiful country, by the way--so much to see and I never made it out of the Dublin area!), and can recall talking with a lot of people about the economic and political developments. At the time, I believe, Ireland was approaching a vote on adopting the Euro as their currency, as I can recall a lot of posters around pro- and anti- the Euro currency.
 
 One thing I noticed a lot of people mentioning or complaining about with regards to the EU was the fact that it had opened the door for an influx of poor immigrants from Eastern Europe. I heard stories of people smuggling themselves into Ireland much as you might hear stories of people smuggling themselves into the US. Most of those noting the phenomenon blamed the generous social policies of the government (I'm not up on what such policies Ireland has, but I'd imagine healthcare and education were up on that list), and saying that such people were pouring in to "freeload" off of the government and Ireland's recent prosperity.
 
 Where does this fit into the picture, if at all?
wilted_laughter

Immigration is a relatively new phenomenon in Ireland, as we were emigrating large numbers of people until our economy turned around. 
 
 As a result immigration has caused a large amount of illogical public hysteria and many Irish people have revealed themselves to be racist.
 
 We need immigration and its a good thing, unfortunately it has declined in recent years. Immigration isn't the problem; people's attitudes to it are.
 
 Generous social policies? I don't know about that!

Ireland experienced a boom in the 1990's partly because of the Hi-tech industry (mainly software). But now those jobs are slowly migrating to Eastern europe , India, China because of cheaper labour costs. Plus it got generous amounts of money from the EU. But now with the expansion of the EU (new members from the poorer eastern european countries), Ireland share of the EU pie is going to be smaller. These two factors combined together will have an impact on Ireland's prosperity in the near future.

What does socialism exactly mean to you ? Government control of all industries? Even 'socialist' Sweden does not have that - it has private industries because that is what works.
 
 
 I am more relaxed than most Socialists towards private enterprise, but I believe key sectors should be directly controlled by the Government and hence directly democratically accountable to the people.
 
 An example of key industries or sectors that should be (or stay) nationalised would be Education, Health care, Transport such as Rail, Bus & ferry(to isolated communities) Network, Police, Air Traffic Control. Apart from that I am quite relaxed on private business involvement other sectors.
 
 As I have said I am quite relaxed and I realise that the market is here to stay in some sectors.

post_info.post_title: Sour grapes for kicking the Hun in WW2

Alan Ryan

Ireland was not an imperial possession. English rule in Ireland predated the age of Imperialism and began in the time of Henry II (the 12th century). Though at first it was "administered" as a crown feoff from which grants of land and powers to dispense "justice" were made to the kings's followers, an English controlled government eventually emerged within the pale around Dublin.
 
 Ireland as a fully independent nation (less the counties in the North of Ireland which are still "loyal" to the British crown) was established by the constitution of 1937.

Capitalism takes into account human nature but controls it to some extent by government intervention such as welfare etc...

 I most also add there many different types of Socialism, there are some that want total control of all industries and others that have a mixed model similar to what we have in most of the West. I am more in line with the Socialist Tradition of the UK where people like John MacLean, Keir Hardie and Nye Bevan. Rather than the branch directly influenced by Marx, Engels which was(is) more prevalent in main Land Europe.
